newsitem.title: CANADA: Laidlaw up on Republic rumors.
newsitem.headline: Laidlaw up on Republic rumors.

text.p: Waste management and transportation firm Laidlaw Inc rose in heavy trade on Wednesday on market rumors that Republic Industries Inc was set to buy Laidlaw's solid waste management component for US$1 billion.
Laidlaw spokesman T.A.G. Watson refuted the speculation, saying: "There's nothing to it. That rumor or variations of it have been around for six months."
Laidlaw gained 0.35 to 13.50 on more than 3.1 million shares. Richardson Greenshields of Canada analyst Dunnery Best reported a large U.S. brokerage had mentioned the speculation.

Best wrote in a report: "Apparently a major U.S. investment house has reported that Laidlaw is about to sell its solid waste operations to Republic Waste Management for about US$1 billion, and apply a portion of the proceeds to repurchase of its shares from Canadian Pacific (Ltd )."
It would cost Laidlaw about C$700 million to buy back its shares, Best said.

"This would then free LDM (Laidlaw) to concentrate on core businesses," which include school bus transportation, ambulances and toxic waste management, Best said. Laidlaw topped Toronto Stock Exchange actives.
Best has a buy rating on the stock and gave it a target of 16.50 in about a year.
An analyst who declined to be identified, said: "This is strictly in the rumor mill."
If Laidlaw were to sell any units, it would sell its whole waste management arm, instead of only the solid waste division, the analyst said.
